issue.title: Nested selects do not work with "src"

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body: I am using jsoup v1.8.2. In jsoup 1.8.1 it was working normally. The nested select does not work in the HTML: https://gist.github.com/remisbaima/70f8cf0c6e3160695791 To reproduce run: ``` java public static void main(final String[] args) throws Exception { final String url = "https://gist.githubusercontent.com/remisbaima/70f8cf0c6e3160695791/raw/54e2ea555e958ef9a8d97c4b1dff119afc957cc0/startpage"; final Document d = Jsoup.parse(new URL(url), 10000); System.out.println(d.select("div#contentgrid_16_2").select("[src=/media/_tech/layout/images/spacer.gif]")); } ``` and you will see in the output only 1 occurrence: ``` html ``` The correct behavior should be that we see 4 occurrences of the "img" above, as when you run: ``` java System.out.println(d.select("[src=/media/_tech/layout/images/spacer.gif]")); ``` you will see 4 occurrences and they are all inside the "div#contentgrid_16_2": ``` html ```

issue.title: Elements.select() does not return all matching Element objects

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
During an upgrade from 1.7.1 to 1.8.3 we have come across an issue that could be a bug, but also could be a misunderstanding. ### Setup test To setup the test, we start with a simple HTML example: ``` html
word
word
``` And then create en Elements object like this: ``` java Document document = Jsoup.parse("...etc..."); Elements elements = document.select("div"); ``` ### Unexpected/Inconsistent behaviour If a `.select()` is run on the `elements` object, it only finds a single instance. E.g. this passes in 1.8.3 but not in 1.7.1: ``` java int elementsFoundUsingSelect = elements.select(":contains(word)").size(); Assert.assertEquals("should find two but finds one", 1, elementsFoundUsingSelect); ``` On the other hand, if I loop over the `elements` object and run a select on each `Element`, I get the following: ``` java int elementsFoundUsingSelect = elements.select(":contains(word)").size(); int elementsFoundUsingLoop = 0; for (Element element : elements) { if (element.select("table:contains(word)").size() > 0) { elementsFoundUsingLoop++; } } Assert.assertEquals("should find two", 2, elementsFoundUsingLoop); ``` ### Expected behaviour I would expect `elements.select(":contains(word)")` to return two elements, but in 1.8.3 it only returns one element. ### Other notes It appears that when the selected HTML content is identical (e.g. the two `
` elements in the above example are identical) than running a `.select()` on the `Elements` object will only select the first object. ### What do I do? Which behaviour is correct? Am I misunderstanding the documentation? - Previously we were relying on the 1.7.1 behaviour to find all instances of an identical element, and then navigate from _each_ of those using `Elements.select()` - However in 1.8.3 you can find all instances of identical elements, but you can't navigate from them using `Elements.select()` as it will only `select()` within the first one.

issue.title: Add breaking tests to test Element.equals

issue.body: Related to #614, #561, and #554, this introduces two tests to assert that selectors return an expected number of elements.
